developerResponse: {'id': 18589958, 'body': "Hey Rebecca!\n\nThank you so much for your feedback! We've fixed this bug, we hope it won't annoy you anymore. Please let us know if you still face any inconveniencies via support@basenjiapps.com. ", 'modified': '2020-10-20T08:28:11Z'}
review:
I downloaded this a track my moods as I quit smoking. It‚Äôs so nice!! I‚Äôm back to download on my new phone, because this app is so pretty and easy to use. I was able to retrieve all my input without creating an account. I‚Äôm so grateful for that! Thank you.
When you delete a message there seems to be no way to restore it; there is no trash file. I think I like that. Yes, I‚Äôm okay with that.
I love the cute little face on the weather-inspired-mood icons. Every day, the app sends me a reminder to make a note, at a time that I set for the day. I love this feature. I don‚Äôt do it often, and it doesn‚Äôt mind.
I also like that I can include activities going on and I can create personalized activities! It really helps to see what else is effecting my mood.
The only complaint I have: it sends me a quote every day. The SAME quote every day for 4 months now. I can‚Äôt find where to switch it up or switch it off. Edit: They have stopped sending the same quote everyday...they have stopped sending any quotes at all. I thought the idea of daily quotes was neat, but the same one everyday was silly. I'm glad they fixed that. Thanks!
title: Really really nice

developerResponse: {'id': 24097495, 'body': 'Thanks for loving Breeze and providing us with such detailed feedback! We‚Äôre sorry to hear you disagree with our current price. But this is how our pricing policy is structured. It‚Äôs important to note that key features are available for free. They include journaling your mood, tracking what influenced it, seeing basic stats on your days, and accessing the first course and test. This set allows you to make progress and improve your mental health. As for premium content, it‚Äôs available when you buy a subscription and helps free content stay so. We understand that price is one of the most important aspects when it comes to choosing the app. Since you love Breeze, please feel free to contact us at support@basenjiapps.com, and we‚Äôll be happy to tell you about our special offers and promotions.', 'modified': '2021-07-23T19:48:19Z'}
review: Now I‚Äôm gonna start off by saying that this app is great! I love the very inclusive and caring feel it gives for people who struggle with mental health, addiction, recovery, etc. BUT this is the downside. We have to pay. Now I know the developers have to make money somehow but that‚Äôs what ads are for. I don‚Äôt want to pay for a subscription for self reporting tests and mood trackers. Respectfully I feel like if the devs truly cared about improvement for individuals and their struggles they would make all resources in this app easily accessible and this could also be a non profit app. Not everyone is gonna have money for this subscription. I know I don‚Äôt, regardless of having a job I have other expenses to take care of so this app would just be a waste of space if I can‚Äôt use it to its full potential. I‚Äôm not saying the company and people who developed this app shouldn‚Äôt get what they earned but like I said before there are ways of making apps free and using ads to gain profit. I would much rather have a great free app and deal with ads rather than having what could‚Äôve been a great app that I unfortunately can‚Äôt use because I can‚Äôt afford it. I understand nothing in this world comes for free but taking care of myself and health shouldn‚Äôt come with an expense. I hope y‚Äôall take my response into consideration cuz I really did like this app. Y‚Äôall just gotta make it inclusive for everyone and anyone who needs it not just people who can afford it.
title: In app subscription.

developerResponse: {'id': 35054161, 'body': "Thank you so much for sharing your thoughts about the app with us! Your feedback has details both about its pros and cons, which is very important to us. Please note that according to the app's structure, there are sets of free and paid features. Breeze's key functionality is free ‚Äî it contains most of the app's features and allows you to journal your mood, track what influenced it, see basic stats on your days, play relaxing games, and access the first course and test. A paid subscription helps these features stay free and gives you access to premium content that consists of other tests and courses. Since you like the app, please feel free to contact us at support@basenjiapps.com to learn about our special offers and promotions ‚Äî we'll be glad to tell you about them!\n\n", 'modified': '2023-02-24T11:49:40Z'}
review: I honestly enjoy the app, it‚Äôs calming and has fun activities to help my boredom. And when tracking your mood it has plenty of options to click which I‚Äôm grateful, it just makes it much easier. But‚Ä¶ almost everything on the app you can‚Äôt do unless you decide to purchase the monthly subscription, WHICH IS SO ANNOYING. I haven‚Äôt bought the subscription yet because I have yet to be paid but I‚Äôm not totally sure I want to. It gives me a gift in the morning when I log in for the day but it‚Äôs always the subscription over and over again asking me to purchase the stupid free trial (WHICH IS ONLY A WEEK LONG, then $8 something monthly) There is the ‚Äúdon‚Äôt show again‚Äù button which is definitely helpful. But not even just that, you can only do several (if even that) of the tests/quizzes without purchasing the subscription. I‚Äôve only been able to do 1 while being ftp!! And there‚Äôs so many tests and quizzes on top of that, so why can‚Äôt you make a little more than a handful free to do?! It also feels like I‚Äôm having the one WEEK free trial shoved down my throat anytime I‚Äôm on the app. So in conclusion, if you can‚Äôt or don‚Äôt want to buy the monthly subscription just don‚Äôt buy the app. There‚Äôs very limited you can do if you do decide to download this and not purchase anything.
title: only good if you spend money

review: I‚Äôm generally a pretty easy person to please and I really don‚Äôt mind paying for apps. But I was very disappointed in the premium version of this app. The aesthetics are very nice, yes, but there is very little substance to the app. As of now, there are only 19 tests, most if not all of which can be found online. The tests are riddled with typos, and some questions make no sense at all. There is also a disappointing number of courses, and they really only explore issues at a very surface level. A paragraph and a few lines of text (at BEST) is what constitutes a lesson. From the high price and advertisements I‚Äôve seen, I was expecting a lot more substance. I have been diagnosed with a few mental issues which are moderate to severe, and I‚Äôve been in therapy for a while. If you‚Äôre considering getting this app and have tried therapy before, it will be a waste. If you‚Äôve never tried therapy, you may get something out of the lessons but it will be very shallow. I recommend checking out other online resources. The ONLY redeemable feature of this app is the mood tracker. I like how you can easily see how your mood fluctuates, the ease in tracking activities related to your moods, and the ability to add a photo to the day is a nice touch. And this feature is absolutely free. In short, free version - worth it. paid version - absolutely not.
title: Don‚Äôt waste your money on this app

review: This app is really well designed and an overall great idea and nice features! The aesthetic is extremely nice and I can tell the devs worked really hard to give the users a nice experience. However, with that being said, the paid subscription feature is extremely ridiculous. Over $8 a week is a bit much if you ask me‚Ä¶ I feel like the addition of a paid subscription at all is a poor choice considering it‚Äôs a MENTAL HEALTH app, designed to make people feel better. It completely goes against what the app is preaching. What makes it worse is that there are little to no free features without the subscription, so the app is almost useless without it. (Pretty much all the tests are locked and most other features are unavailable as well.) The daily mood thing is nice, and I like how it tracks how you feel each time you fill it out but that‚Äôs just about the most useful thing on there without the subscription. I feel as though the subscription should just be removed completely, because it seems really selfish of the devs to add such a thing. I understand that they might need money, but the high price they‚Äôre asking is just not right. At the very least, price should be much, much lower than it is‚Ä¶
title: It has great potential! But has a major issue‚Ä¶

developerResponse: {'id': 39128622, 'body': "We apologize for any inconvenience you've faced with the data loss issue. We recommend reaching out to our support team at support@bsnj.co for further assistance and guidance regarding your situation. Your feedback is important, and our support team will work to provide the best possible assistance they can.", 'modified': '2023-09-25T14:49:47Z'}
review: The app was great until it randomly deleted all of my information. I typically used the app to log my good days so I could come back and re live those memories, and I loved how you could even add a cute little picture to your note, it really took me back and I could visualize and remember the day I was looking back on. Sometimes you forget about those little sweet moments, so I liked to be able to jot them down and keep them. Unfortunately one day I opened the app and everything was gone. I‚Äôm talking like a good couple months to a year of days and experiences I wrote down. It was so disappointing I don‚Äôt know what happened, I don‚Äôt recall there being a ‚Äúdelete everything‚Äù button. I didn‚Äôt purposely try to erase anything. I just use the app like normal every time when adding all my stuff. When I say everything was gone I mean EVERYTHING. Even the activities and emotions you can choose that it automatically starts with. I‚Äôll have to go back and re add every positive and negative emotion choice and all the possible activities. Because now there is nothing to choose from. I liked how in the beginning how it already had those and I could add more if I wanted. So now I‚Äôm not sure if I want to keep using this anymore because like what‚Äôs the point of using it and adding everything back if all my data is going to get randomly erased again.
title: I am unsure how to feel

developerResponse: {'id': 25607936, 'body': "We're sorry to hear that. üòüOur team will be looking for ways to solve this problem, we really want to make your experience with the app great. If you like the functionality, feel free to contact us at support@basenjiapps.com, so we can share special offers and promotions with you.", 'modified': '2021-10-11T08:30:57Z'}
review: I feel part of the reason so many are upset is due to advertising on the apps end, I occasionally run across advertisements that say try for free, and sure I may not expect it to be free, however when you show a specific test, or someone using a specific feature thats locked behind a pay wall, i'd say there is an issue. Putting a try for free while also placing someone taking a test that you'd have to pay for is poor advertising, sure maybe you get someone to download it but it ends up being frustrating and misleading. Considering the app focuses on helping, it can be a huge let down for people to download an app, and realize they can't afford it and it's way too costly. I have downloaded this in the past, but not for the free features, and due to the features locked behind money I was fairly quick to uninstall. I only came back today due to an ad that was very misleading. Fix your ads for this because this app is not as free as you make it out to be. Once you do that i'm sure it'd be a lot better, because at the moment when I clicked it there was a lot of try for frees all over the site, when you only have a small amount actually accessible to people. I would likely retract my bad rating and review if that problem was actually fixed.
title: Misleading advertisement

review:
Some of the quizzes are great, but others are not. when it ask you about how your work effects you, how on earth am I as a disabled person who can‚Äôt work supposed to answer those kind of things? It assumes everyone can work, which is a bunch of boloney! Also, add some quizzes for abusive familial and friend relationships too. Not everyone has experienced a relationship, especially people like me who is autistic and has trouble with social cues, which makes it harder for people to like me. Not saying that is the case for every autistic person, but for me, my social cue issues come off too weird for people to want to be with me as a partner. A lot of people need help figuring out if their family or friends are abusive to them, so those would really beneficial kind of quizzes. Not everyone wants a relationship with people in a romantic way anyways. 

I do like other quizes such as the masculine and feminine psych test, which helped me feel affirmed with the result of androgynous. I also liked the ADHD and depression/anxiety tests, and so forth.
title: Not inclusive to disabled people in quizes

review: This app was not a breeze for me. I really love the concept of this app. I think it‚Äôs a brilliant idea and can truly help others gain new perspectives, even benefit themselves! However, the payment factor is an unfortunate one. Not to mention, they‚Äôre expensive. You‚Äôre paying 8.49 a week so around 50 dollars üíµ per month. Have fun with that one. I understand the developers have to make money somehow and if they‚Äôre reading this, they‚Äôve probably already seen a lot of the views have a similar saying. I honestly downloaded this app for the QUIZZES. I like taking such along the topics. However, only ONE quiz that I found, out of around 16 of them, is for FREE. Most of the other lessons weren‚Äôt for free either and pretty much all you can do is record/track your day, play about for games (which was my favorite part, and that‚Äôs honestly all that I can think of. The only reason I‚Äôm giving this game 2 stars is just because of the idea and game concepts. If they allow more quizzes to be free and other features, I think more people would stay around longer (as most you can just take along.) Either way, I appreciate them reading these reviews and responding back. Please have a lovely day!
title: Payments are necessary for a lot of the content

developerResponse: {'id': 23873815, 'body': "Thanks for sharing your feedback with us. We're truly sorry to hear about the problems, and we'd love to solve them. Your comment helps a lot. Also, if you have some screenshots to share, feel free to email us at support@basenjiapps.com. Thanks for helping us be better!", 'modified': '2021-07-12T07:52:32Z'}
review:
This app doesn‚Äôt make any sense, there are typos everywhere. For example, the pre-loaded markers for ‚Äúwhat are you doing‚Äù when you submit a mood (e.g. ‚Äúsad‚Äù) have some normal things like exercise and eating, but also some that are not even activities like, ‚Äútravel tips.‚Äù The quizzes have questions that aren‚Äôt comprehensive by any means, which would be ok if they made any sense. The questions are sometimes not just poorly worded, but actually nonsensical. I hope no one uses these quizzes to figure out if they have signs of anxiety etc. I don‚Äôt know where they got these assessments but they appear autogenerated or something. For example, it will say ‚Äúhow often do you feel sad?‚Äù And then the options will be ‚Äúnot at all, mildly - it didn‚Äôt impact me.‚Äù The subscription is incredibly expensive for what this app is, which leads me to believe this is a scam. I used it for free for one day before canceling. I recommend using a different app.

Update: I received a response asking for screen shots. I sent one screen shot to the developer, however the issues I‚Äôm citing above are so blatant and everywhere that it‚Äôs difficult for me to believe this is a bug. I would encourage anyone considering this app to exercise caution.
title: This app is a scam.

developerResponse: {'id': 26558273, 'body': "Thanks for contacting us. We're truly sorry about your experience. We know about the problem with this test and currently working on fixing it.", 'modified': '2021-11-30T11:47:11Z'}
review: I took the test for mood disorders, which is basically the test for bipolar. I‚Äôm able to answer yes to every single question, including the question that asks if a health professional has ever said I have bipolar. YES. I also was able to answer YES to the experiencing mixed episodes where you have more than once symptom at one time. The ONLY question I answered no to was having a hereditary or genetic disposition to it, no one in my family has been officially diagnosed. And this app over and over says I have a negative result. That‚Äôs about all I need to know about the credibility of this app, when I say yes to every symptom I‚Äôve experienced with my bipolar II, yes to a medical professional diagnosis (which I have), and the app still says I have a normal range. This is a laughable algorithm they have developed. Oh dear. Cancelled the subscription after about three other tests were taken, results were less than impressive as someone who‚Äôs been heartily enmeshed in the therapy game for a long time. Not worth anyones time. Didn‚Äôt even last a whole two hours, and you get a free week subscription. Bye bye apple subscription. What a wasted click bait on an Instagram ad. Can we rate this lower than one star? No?
title: Full of bad results

developerResponse: {'id': 30049862, 'body': "Thank you so much for such profound feedback! We'll use it to improve the app. Also, if you have some time, you're very welcome to email us some screenshots of the questions you've mentioned at support@basenjiapps.com. We appreciate your interest in Breeze!", 'modified': '2022-05-30T11:47:00Z'}
review: First of all, as a graphic designer, I think that the illustrations and actual app design is excellent. I do like the concept of this app and the games are more helpful than I anticipated. I‚Äôve done a few of the quizzes and I‚Äôm not a fan of the polarization in the answers when they only give two answers. Sometimes we are in between answers‚Ä¶there should be a slider scale or maybe 5 different answers varying on how well the user identifies with the statement. As a cis woman, I was a bit surprised to see the sexist trends in the gender quiz. The ideas of ambition, assertiveness, etc ascribed to men and gentleness, empathy, etc. pinned to women is very reductive. Of course I got an ‚Äúandrogynous‚Äù result because I consider myself self sufficient and ambitious. I don‚Äôt think that makes me any less feminine. The other quizzes confused me in the results, as I very much resonated with every emotional burnout question and yet was given a ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù result. I also saw a few typos. Perhaps once the kinks are worked out, maybe this app could be more of a successful tool. At the very least, it‚Äôs aesthetically pleasing.
title: Cute UI/UX, questionable tests

developerResponse:
{'id': 25485324, 'body': 'Thanks for your feedback!

As for a "writing style" test, sometimes we show the features we'd love to add in the future. We're sorry that the tests that are already in our app fail to meet your expectations. As for the conflicting answers, it can occur in case you gave different answers to the same questions that were paraphrased.

Please feel free to share the screenshots of the troubled tests by contacting us at support@basenjiapps.com, so we could fix the issue quicker.

As for the price, if you like functionality, then it's another reason to contact us at the email mentioned above, so we could share our special offers and promotions with you.', 'modified': '2021-10-04T15:45:16Z'}
review:
I found this app because it advertised a ‚Äúwriting style‚Äù test on Instagram. As a writer, I was curious. After downloading, I took a couple of the tests - though none of it was relevant to writing or was the test I had seen advertised. The tests were all yes/no questions, and I reached an error screen after each, saying that my answers were conflicting and the app couldn‚Äôt give me results - and that I should retake the test again. 

Unlike Myers Briggs, which scores on a gradient of answers, the wording and grammar wasn‚Äôt very clear, and again, I got another error screen stating that my answers were conflicting. I am rating two stars for the poor grammar and quality of tests, inaccurate advertisement, and ridiculous pricing after the initial free trial. $35+ per month‚Ä¶?! For an app that isn‚Äôt clear or cohesive? The creators should really revisit their design, target audience, and pricing, because while I see the potential upsides to a functional app with these same intentions, this is just unrealistic.
title: Who made this?

review: imma start this off by saying this app is developed well and that it‚Äôs well organized and it could really help with your mental health theres quizzes to teach you about it but the down fall is that you have to pay. i understand that the developers need a way to get money but there‚Äôs other ways to get it like using ads or something and it‚Äôs not to much for the subscription but for someone like me i‚Äôm low on money and i thought this app would be able to help with my mental stability right now but i can‚Äôt spend my money on this app i already have trouble paying the bills like i said before there‚Äôs other ways you can get money besides having to pay a subscription. without the subscription you can track yourself and have a journal that‚Äôs about it with the subscription you get to take the quizzes and learn about your mental health and much more but if you really cared about the mental state of others you wouldn‚Äôt have the subscription on how to learn about it i mean i get the quizzes but we still need to be able to learn about our health and how to fix the issue. if you read all of that thank you for listening.
title: Subscription

review:
I have been trying to cancel my trial membership but cannot get an answer from anyone. I have emailed your support as well as reached out on Instagram, where I initially signed up thru an ad you had there, and all I have received is what appears to be an auto-generated response on Instagram as no one has replied to me since then. I signed up thru your website, as I was directed to it from your ad, then downloaded the app after that. There is nowhere to cancel my trial membership. No options in the app, no links to your website and nothing I can find by searching for breeze or basenji, the parent company. I also checked subscriptions on PayPal and there is nothing there as well. The app seems nice enough but is just not for me and I want this cancelled before I get charged (I was on day 4 when first reaching out). The lack of response is extreme frustrating and aggravating. I am posting here because I don‚Äôt know what else to do and hope to see a timely response. 

Be very weary of signing up for the trial as there is apparently no way to easily cancel if you sign up thru one of their ads/online quizes!
title: Cannot cancel trial membership

review: This was a really great app. I saw an ad for it on TikTok and downloaded it. I loved the features and the graphics. I also liked the assessments and the fact that it really delved into mental health and the underlying things behind it, rather than just giving you run-of-the-mill information. Seemed well thought out. Sadly, I‚Äôm only giving it one star because there is no way to change your email if you type it in incorrectly during the sign-up process, which unfortunately I did. There is also no support email listed on the app, and I had to go to the website to find a support email. I emailed them a month ago asking if I could have it changed to my correct email, and I never got a response. This is very problematic because an incorrect email could be receiving your personal health information or other details, and there is no way to fix it. If I‚Äôm going to pay $8 a month for an app, I expect there to be a way to change your email or to get a response from customer service. I hope they fix this issue.
title: Liked the app but no way to change email

developerResponse: {'id': 25677832, 'body': "Thank you for your feedback. We're sorry to hear that. Our team will do our best to improve the app and make your experience with Breeze great. If you like the functionality, but the current pricing structure does not match your budget, feel free to contact us at support@basenjiapps.com, so we can share special offers and promotions with you. We kindly ask you to update the application, and you can add works or whatever you want. ", 'modified': '2021-10-14T08:52:27Z'}
review:
Let‚Äôs begin with the most important thing: after your free trial, the app is $8.50 per WEEK. That‚Äôs $34 per month. That is a ton of money: basically as much as cable television, but for a mood-tracking app. I‚Äôm not sure what I‚Äôm paying for here: it features quizzes (like the now-discredited Myers-Briggs personality type) that can be easily obtained for free online. And I found it confusing that in the ‚Äúwhat are you doing right now‚Äù section of tracking one‚Äôs activities and mood, there is no option for ‚Äúwork‚Äù or ‚Äúchores‚Äù! So, this app would be great if you are a wealthy heir/heiress who never works and you want to track how you respond to eating, playing, and hanging out with friends. I didn‚Äôt need the full week‚Äôs trial- I knew right away that this wasn‚Äôt for me, and canceled my subscription after less than a day.

While I can appreciate that this app was clearly designed by someone for whom English is a second language, there are so many typos, misspellings, and mis-translations that it becomes distracting.
title: Very expensive and many things lost in translation

developerResponse:
{'id': 34594996, 'body': "Thank you so much for taking the time to share this profound feedback with us! We deeply appreciate it.

As for the wording, some questions can be tricky according to the initial idea of the questionnaire. We don't invent tests ourselves; instead, we take well-known tests to give our users more reliable results. We try to let people get a moderately profound experience without going too deep since even well-known tests cannot guarantee you a perfectly accurate result, and self-diagnostic should not be taken as an unquestionable truth. Otherwise, it can bring more harm than use. Our goal with Breeze is not to replace a specialist but to help people better understand themselves and pay attention to what should be done to improve their mental well-being.

The same about the right questions: we didn't replace the existing questions from the tests to keep the accuracy of results.

The log is simple for a reason: we keep it that way to help our users choose their mood quickly instead of getting lost in shades of feelings.

To resume, we'd love to say that we hope Breeze will be the right tool for those who want to improve their well-being and don't see the app as the final solution or something that can replace consulting a specialist and correct medical treatment. We just want Breeze to help people find the direction and start positive changes ‚Äî we know it can be hard, so we're here to help take the very first steps.

We hope it clarifies the situation! Again, we truly appreciate your time and feedback and will use it for future growth. Please feel free to contact us at support@basenjiapps.com to share your thoughts and ideas ‚Äî we're always up for it!
", 'modified': '2023-01-31T15:56:07Z'}
review:
The questions on most personality tests have two answers that sometimes are not things that you would identify with for either and sometimes the questions themselves are strangely worded or asked in a way you don‚Äôt identify yourself with, or agree with, instead of with neutrality or inquisitiveness. Some of the questions are odd in themselves such as being strangely worded, feeling incomplete, or as if they were translated from a different language. The mood disorders quiz feels way too short and simplistic to be telling someone to look out for possible bi-polar disorder when a lot of these same answers to their questions could be associated with ADHD such as impulsiveness, energy, and talkativeness

Some of the quizzes can be insightful if they actually manage to ask the right questions and supply the right answers, and mostly if it seems to be a simple subject, such as a depression, anger, abusive relationships, etc. 

The daily mood log is overly simplistic, with only five options, ranging from very sad, sad, neutral, happy, to very happy with no other moods or feelings outside of that spectrum. 

All in all this feels like a kids app or like a very basic researched series of small quizzes in the back of a magazine. I wouldn‚Äôt use this if you actually care to understand anything serious about yourself unless you‚Äôre absolutely clueless about yourself and your feelings or the way you deal with things.
title: Overly simplistic

review:
I found this app. very cool but there is one.. not problem but thing I can‚Äôt do. 
     I don‚Äôt have the money to spend on an app like this. I did the free trial and it was great but when it ended I could only access very few things. 
     I understand that people need to make money in ways and that is how they make money but for people like me, who can‚Äôt spend the money on an app (difference between can‚Äôt and don‚Äôt want too) can‚Äôt access the whole thing and stuff that could and would help us. I‚Äôm not saying to change the whole app to be free cause I understand you need to make money as much as I do but I can spend my money on stuff like this.
      I understand your purpose of this app and I think it is great for people who have money to spend and think it would be a great investment to spend it on this I just individually can‚Äôt. But keep doing what you are doing and I think you will change peoples lives for the better. <3 Nikki
title: Okay but..

review: I could absolutely guarantee that there is genuinely no science to back up any single thing on this app other than what has been ripped from official PHQ assessments which you can take by yourself for free anywhere. These BuzzFeed style ‚Äúmental health assessments‚Äù are very degrading and please seek actual assistance from someone who respects you and you can trust to give you information like your ‚Äútoxic trait‚Äù and if you‚Äôre a ‚Äúmanipulator‚Äù. I don‚Äôt even hate the idea but to label these things so negatively and then their added ‚Äúcute‚Äù little graphics to represent it adds a layer of arrogance and doesn‚Äôt take mental health issues seriously. We all have toxic traits, the creators of this‚Äô toxic trait is thinking they‚Äôre better than everyone else. Don‚Äôt waste your money on these pretentious people who want to label you, there are free resources to mental health clinics in times of need and if you‚Äôre feeling down on yourself remember these labels do not define you. Shame on yourself Breeze.
title: Please don‚Äôt download this app if you have actual mental health issues

developerResponse: {'id': 35627968, 'body': "Thank you so much for sharing your impressions with us. We're happy to know you've found the courage to change your life for the better and chose Breeze to help you do it. We hope you'll become happier and reach tranquility, and may our app keep on providing you with the support you need!", 'modified': '2023-03-28T07:27:52Z'}
review: Was depressed to the point of hopelessness. Started using this app on a whim after seeing an ad bc I didn‚Äôt know what else I could do. While it is no replacement for therapy, I can say it has helped me learn about myself and find some direction. Initially I just hoped to notice patterns in my mood tracking, but then I found that logging those moods every day helped ground me. I have been able to figure out what parts of my life make me feel better and worse, and the guides/lessons do genuinely help me figure out how to move forward. Plus, the option of adding a photo w each mood card has cheered me up a bit just because it‚Äôs fun, it feels expressive, and it encourages me to DO things. F app subscriptions but I pay for this one and only this one.
title: Surprised, helps inspire motivation

developerResponse: {'id': 15996044, 'body': "Thank you so much for this detailed and useful review! üôèüèª\nWe're really glad that if we could help to make your life easier with our app. That's what we've made it for ‚ù§Ô∏è", 'modified': '2020-06-15T13:39:08Z'}
review: I recently started antidepressants and have been looking for an app to track my moods throughout the day. I had a hard time finding one that allowed for multiple daily entries that works without paying a premium or subscription fee. This one is really user friendly, allows you to add custom activities and tracks these and how they correlate with your different moods. This is super helpful for me for understanding other factors than my meds that may be influencing my moods, such as coffee or a stressful conversation. Overall just very helpful and easy to use for specific individual needs. There is like an ad watching for credit system but these credits are not needed for the main features, and so the ads have not been disruptive to my experience at all. Highly recommend.
title: Really helpful and actually free, wow

developerResponse:
{'id': 39077980, 'body': "We appreciate your detailed feedback and understand your perspective. It's clear that you have a strong sense of self-awareness and have been actively working on yourself, which is commendable.

Your insights regarding the test format and the need for more nuanced questions are valuable. We aim to provide a valuable experience for a wide range of users, and your feedback helps us identify areas for improvement.

While our app may be more beneficial for individuals who are new to self-reflection or therapy, we acknowledge that it may not suit everyone's needs, especially those who have extensive experience in this area.

Your feedback is important, and we're committed to continuously improving our app to better serve our users. If you have any further suggestions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. We appreciate your input in helping us enhance our services.", 'modified': '2023-09-22T12:47:18Z'}
review:
If you already have a sense of self awareness, or are already working on yourself through therapy or more, then this app simply is not worth your time and definitely not the cost of subscription.

The tests feel amateurish and frankly too rigid to be of any help. Most questions have only two answers to choose from and it basically boils down to yes or no. That‚Äôs simply not helpful for me and likely many others like me who might struggle making black and white statements and decisions. Nothing in life is so simple as, ‚Äòdo you do this or that,‚Äô and the lack of nuance and circumstantial answers makes me question the value of whatever results they may provide.

This might be useful for people who don‚Äôt realize that they could benefit from self reflection or therapy. Maybe someone who never trusted therapy  - perhaps this could be something like a gateway to self discovery and healing, and then they have an epiphanous realization that maybe they could benefit from it after all? 

But I‚Äôve lived with whatever you want to call my issues for twenty some years now. I‚Äôve already started trying to heal and feel better, and I‚Äôve learned a considerable amount about myself in the process. So for me, and others who have lived most of their lives with these issues and illnesses and whatnot, this isn‚Äôt going to do much.
title: Rather shallow - not useful if you‚Äôre already getting help

review: I saw an ad for this app on IG so I installed it. I quickly realized if I wanted to take the tests I would need a premium subscription so I subscribed because I‚Äôm a sucker for internet quizzes. As many people have mentioned there is some weird language issue with some questions ‚Äî and I also found none of the numbers show up.  For example on the internet addiction test, it was like ‚ÄúI spend more than hours on the internet.‚Äù Right. (I am not going to email the developer with screenshots as I have already canceled my subscription and uninstalled the app.) I also found the results to be pretty inaccurate. I took the ‚Äúintrovert/extrovert‚Äù quiz and for the record, I am a complete introvert, but after answering all the questions that way, the result said I was 50/50 extro and intro, that I am outgoing and like to be out with people. Say what? ü§î I gave it 2 stars because it was entertaining for about 30 minutes and the app is pretty well-made.
title: Not worth it

review:
Dude oh my gosh, I just took the ‚Äúmasculine or feminine inside‚Äù (idk if that‚Äôs the actual name I just clicked on it) test and it says I‚Äôm androgynous. Are you kidding? ‚ÄúAre you dominant, are you soft spoken, are you unconventional‚Äù that stuff doesn‚Äôt define what a person‚Äôs gender is. It‚Äôs misleading to people like I‚Äôm not the most gentle woman around but I‚Äôm very strongly a woman. Mentally and physically and I‚Äôm confident in that, I‚Äôve always been a tomboy but that doesn‚Äôt make me internally a male!! It means I like doing the more masculine things sometimes like throwing a football with guys rather than going into a dance party, but that alone doesn‚Äôt determine my gender mentally or physically. I‚Äôm lucky I‚Äôm so confident in myself because if I wasn‚Äôt, I‚Äôd be questioning my entire existence right now. 

But the mood logging and other personality tests work very well for me

review: i really love this app! it has a really cute design that makes me want to use the app even more often. i really like the slider feature to choose your mood. although, if it is after a certain time of day, it changes the entry to the next day, instead of the current day? and there‚Äôs no way to edit this. when i go into the edit section, it says it is some day in September 2018. also, i got rid of all the presets in the ‚Äúwhat have you been up to‚Äù section, because i wanted to only have my own, but the ‚Äò+‚Äô button went away when i deleted a few of them. so there is no way to add more anymore!! i really like the app, and the design is so cute!! i could get past the sometimes having the wrong date, but i hate that i‚Äôm going to have to uninstall and lose all of my entries, and reinstall in order to get the ‚Äúwhat have you been up to‚Äù thingys back.
title: kind of buggy but i really like it

review: I just downloaded this an hour ago, finally went to try it and the second I was prompted with having to pay for the full aspects of this app I felt lied to with the ad I saw on Tiktok. False advertising at its finest. As an individual who is studying psychology to become a therapist it does annoy me that any ‚Äúmental health app‚Äù out there you always have to pay stupid amounts of money to use features on the app. When will people understand that mental health and illnesses are not and should not be profitable. These are actual people having issues, trying to find accessible help and are being made to believe, as I was, that this is an app free of use. I also saw another review speaking on the same things of charging people and not being able to afford it with other living expenses, to which I highly agree with, and their response was all business talk, not really addressing the real issue. Nevertheless I will be deleting this app after submitting this.
title: Barely used the app

review:
I haven‚Äôt been using this app for very long, but I already love it! I love that you can customize your activities and that there is a wide range in emotions bigger than going from ‚Äúsad‚Äù to ‚Äúhappy.‚Äù I like that you can track your sleep; this feature has been especially helpful for me.
There are, however, a few features I don‚Äôt like. I don‚Äôt like that you have to get gratitude points to use a passcode, I feel like that should just be a given option. There is a bug that doesn‚Äôt allow me to edit past entries, which is frustrating and would be much better if they could be fixed. I‚Äôm also unsure of how to delete entries, or if it‚Äôs even possible to do.
Overall the app is great, and the pros outweigh the cons, but there are some adjustments that can be made.
title: Really like it!!

review:
There are many strengths to this app and many many weaknesses. Downloaded this to analyze for my clinical psychology course and found the app to struggle with a diverse collection for its users. The weekly $8.49 isn't a good idea to get users to directly want to pay. Perhaps a Monthly or Annual fee would be a better option to users who are likely rather than simply needing to use the app for a week or 2 they would likely need it for a month or longer. I don't feel like enough disorders are covered on the app. The only thing the user can use without a subscription is the mood journal. There needs to be more disorders listed, more inventories, more questionnaires... and perhaps less vague results for the users and a direct help of numbers stated if the person indicates a need for help.

These are my opinions!

title: I would give this 4.8 stars

review:
the test: ‚Äúdetermine your psychological gender‚Äù 
the questions: are you happy? 

 so. that‚Äôs a bit weird. a lot of the gender test is like that, actually. 
 the developers have said that this isn‚Äôt a diagnostic tool, of course, but‚Ä¶. i have been clinical diagnosed with major generalized anxiety, major depressive disorder, along with ocd for some time now.
 my results on both the anxiety and depression test told me i had ‚Äú‚Äù‚Äùminor‚Äù‚Äù‚Äù depression and anxiety. 
i think this app has loads of potential, but so many of the tools they use are outdated and don‚Äôt recognize ‚Äúnon traditional‚Äù symptoms of mental illness. you know how a lot of psychology is centered around young white men? this is that, if that concept was an app. 

a lot of the tests are incredibly black and white, too. like, you can be both logical and sympathetic. those things aren‚Äôt contradictions. people are multifaceted.

i don‚Äôt think i need to point out the obvious issue with the payment being insanely high for a low quality service. run ads, y‚Äôall, there is absolutely no reason this should cost 9$/ WEEK. but, nearly everyone else has already said that in better words, so. go check those reviews out.

also, using someone‚Äôs independence as a way to measure their gender is hella weird. do better.

review:
Multiple quizzes said I have low empathy. I have spent the last 10 years devoting my life to working with marginalized communities and helping others. Anyone who knows me knows that being empathetic is my greatest strength. After seeing those results, I couldn‚Äôt take any of the other quizzes seriously. They are honestly so bad and not research-based at all.  Not to mention, so many of the questions are poorly written, make very little sense, and have multiple typos. 

Making customers pay $8.50 PER WEEK for such an unprofessional and fraudulent app is a scam. DO NOT use this app as a mental health resource. There are plenty of free resources online that are real and backed by research, not just made up. If you‚Äôre going to pay for mental health resources, your money will be far better spent with a certified therapist or on resources that come from reputable sources. Don‚Äôt waste money on this app.
title: Quizzes are awful, app is a scam

review: The aesthetic is nice and I like the intention behind this app, but it is way overpriced and it has a long way to go. You could get a monthly gym membership for the price of one week of this app, and honestly that would be much better for your mental health. Im addition to this 9.99 a month gets you very little content. To charge this much reasonably, the app would need to have 20x as much content. Yet as of now, all of their education and quizzes are readily accessible for FREE online. Yes the app has a nice aesthetic and the mood tracker is helpful, but it is incredibly overpriced and it‚Äôs main focus is maximizing profits from people who are struggling with mental health. All in all it very disappointing to see an app taking advantage of people like this.
title: Over priced, under developed

review:

 Friday April 5th
Ok, so I just updated the app. I‚Äôm not very thrilled about the 7.99 a week price. I can‚Äôt afford that. I absolutely love the idea and the app. But now I‚Äôm not sure I can even use it..

Also the time And date are all wrong in my journal. I need a settings button so I can adjust them. It‚Äôs very strange.

Bumped down to 2 stars from 5 because of the price
title: Great app so far

review: I like this app a lot. The free version offers a lot that most journal tracking apps don‚Äôt. It‚Äôs easy to enter information and the statistics are clear and informative. I use it on my iPhone and iPad and wish it had an actual iPad version rather than a blown-up version of the iPhone app. With a lot of iPads being used with keyboards, it‚Äôs nice to be able to type in an HD iPad version of the app. It‚Äôs become my go-to journal app, replacing some others that I was using long-term. I especially like the gratitude prompt which encourages me to write about things I‚Äôm grateful for that day. That really forces me to pause and think about what I liked about my day, rather than just the things I didn‚Äôt like about my day.
title: Needs an iPad version

developerResponse: {'id': 39753376, 'body': "We apologize for the inconvenience you've experienced. We never intend to make the process difficult for our users. If you have more questions or need further assistance, please reach out to our support team. Thank you for sharing your concerns.", 'modified': '2023-10-26T10:47:37Z'}
review: You‚Äôd think a mental health / wellness app would care more about its users than making a profit.. but *surprise* they don‚Äôt lol ü§° Upon signing up for the ‚Äúfree‚Äù trial, it stated that you can cancel the subscription at any time.. false. There was no option in iPhone settings > Apple ID > subscriptions to cancel the subscription. You have to email them. When I emailed them they tried to tell me to try to cancel on my own (as if I hadn‚Äôt already done my own research and tried and only reached out to them as a last resort). Then somehow they stated the subscription was *magically* cancelled (after charging me yday).. and did not explain as to how when I asked and by whom. At no point did I authorize the weekly payments and at no point did I select the ‚Äúpremium level‚Äù subscription. They also claimed to not handle the refund process.
title: beware SCAM: $$$ > mental health

review:
There are a lot of ways to pay for apps and services, subscriptions are definitely one. 
However when your customer base are people seeking help for mental health, a company has a responsibility to ensure their marketing represents their attitude in how the service is payed for.
the price is not necessary unfair and subscription isn‚Äôt a bad way to pay for a continuous benefit. my problem is the marketing behind it. Exploiting your consumers, who are seeking actual mental help, by saying ‚ÄúFREE this  FREE that FREE‚Äù and then immediately limiting them and not giving any resources to help other than in app shows a lack of care for people who were hopeful to, at minimum, get what they were advertised as free. 
You have a great tool to help people in need, especially with the world on fire right now, but this company definitely knows where their priorities lie, in profits and gains.
title: Money>people

review: The irony is pretending to be woke by calling potentially mentally ill people toxic or non toxic, like human beings are glue bottles or paint cans. the slap in the face it is to see the question ‚Äúmy life has been very difficult and challenging‚Äù on a ‚Äútoxic person‚Äù quiz as if the developers of this app couldn‚Äôt fathom someone with access to this technology being someone who has suffered in life. If a previously or currently homeless veteran or trafficking survivor or DV survivor or child abused survivor, ETC took this quiz and they said they had struggled in life, would that count towards them being toxic or non toxic to you? please don‚Äôt cause more of us to be pushed to self injury or worse because you fancy yourselves mental health advocates and can‚Äôt even deduce that traumatized people may be using this app too. Oh but everything about mental health, understanding past and present traumas, and test taking to figure yourself out..yea you have to pay for those and really the only thing you can do for free on the cash grab of an app is track your moods, feelings, and thoughts (you know..stuff you could do in the note app in your phone or on a piece of paper) I forgot we live in a day and age where mental health is marketable, my bad. title: Great idea, VERY VERY POOR execution

developerResponse: {'id': 39181472, 'body': "Thank you for your feedback. We'd like to clarify that the initial quiz is indeed free of charge. We offer a premium trial for our app which is an optional paid service, and the terms and conditions for this are clearly disclosed before any purchase is made. You can opt-out at any time before or after the purchase. For any concerns about billing or personal data, please contact our support team at support@bsnj.co. We're committed to resolving any issues you may have.", 'modified': '2023-09-27T16:12:53Z'}
review:
This company uses a technique in which they offer a ‚Äúfree quiz‚Äù to help people assess their needs as a marketing tactic. They don‚Äôt disclose there will be a price. Or mandatory submission of personal information prior to accessing the assessment. 

In addition, the free trial isn‚Äôt free. 

They force the person to choose how much they‚Äôll pay for the ‚Äúfree trial‚Äù prior to even gaining full access to the free assessment that started the whole mess. This manipulative, coercive approach to making money is sickening.

To make it even more illegal, once on this page, the victim of this slimy company now has only one option: Continue and accept the terms of service and privacy policy‚Ä¶or contact their privacy officer by email to demand the deletion of all information collected up to that moment. 

They literally do not offer the option to click ‚ÄúNo‚Äù or ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù. This isn‚Äôt just frustrating and unethical. It violates federal law. 

If a company claims to want to help people but uses deception and manipulation to get money and marketable information from them before ever assisting anyone in any way‚Ä¶you can bet that company has one goal and one goal only. And it‚Äôs not to help YOU.
title: Coercive bait and switch; zero trust.

review:
As many others have reported, the quizzes are riddled with typos and contain a lot of leading language. Many of the questions in the Enneagram personality quiz in particular are full of language that is not truly neutral, making choosing authentically difficult. I would recommend an adjustment that takes into consideration pairings of words (all of the answers are binary with only two options) that are imbalanced in their negative or positive connotations. If one provided choice has a clearly negative connotation, people will want to choose the other one, even if it contradicts the way they see themselves. It is not a matter of perspective, but what we agree upon collectively as language users. 

As many others have said, there are also many typos that cause confusion.

Also- ‚ÄúMan‚Äù or ‚Äúfemale‚Äù in the picture quiz ??? Really?????? Immediately made me exit the app in disgust. This reinforces and encourages transphobia, directly. Clearly this is an app for the cis. 

I think there is value in recording habits and moods, and am sure that many people will get a lot out of this app for that reason. I just don‚Äôt feel comfortable doing so after taking these messed up quizzes.
title: Quizzes are messed up

review: Let‚Äôs start with the personality test. There is no option for ‚Äúunsure‚Äù or ‚Äúcan‚Äôt decide‚Äù. Sometimes two options will be equally appealing. Therefore it will produce incorrect or inaccurate results the majority of the time. As for the career test, most of it asks ‚Äúcan you do(said skills)‚Äù just because I can do something doesn‚Äôt mean that is what I want to do. If I can repair dry wall in my home that doesn‚Äôt mean I want to be in construction. How is this $9 a week and they can‚Äôt even produce remotely accurate results. It needs to be scale based. ‚ÄúOn a scale of 1 - 10 how does this fit with you‚Äù or something similar. Really just feels like a scam and a way for them to get money. Insanely unimpressed and probably one of the worst personality/career tests I have ever come across.
title: Nonsense

review: I downloaded this app out of curiosity as a very self aware person. This app provides very basic information and feed back from the various personality and mental health quizzes they offer. The information provided as results seems very limited. For example the personality test says I am one personality type when I know I am actually between 2 about 50/50. The app doesn‚Äôt allow for multiple type feedback. Also in the add I saw it said it offered a particular quiz that it does not. Overall it is a good place to start if you‚Äôre just starting on your self awareness journey, definitely not for someone who is well versed in self awareness.

review: As an autistic individual, mental health to me is expensive enough as is, not just talking about money. Either way, psychological help can be pricey, however, it is PROFESSIONAL help from a LICENSED professional in which most people put money into. Not a stupid app that just provides questionnaires and daily check-ins, I get all of that plus more via therapy/psychiatry lol. If this was a free app, I would definitely rate 5 stars. If it was at least mentioned in the app description that it requires money, I‚Äôd give it 2 stars at minimum after downloading, considering the disappointment would be on me if I clicked download without reading. review:
This app was great! It is kind of like upgraded Reflectly (which is a great app, totally recommend.)

It allows you to...

1. Journal your feelings.
On the plus button it allows you to say how you feel, why you feel it, and it puts it in your Moods box! üåª

2. Knowledge.
It has classes and reading that are there for your sake. Although most have to be unlocked, some are free as Depression 101. That leads us to the bad part.

The only down thing about this app was that most of the features on the app cost money for a monthly subscription. I haven‚Äôt bought it because I don‚Äôt feel the need to. (Fantastic self care has a lot of free features, so if I need I can log on there.) but I do think we should be able to have things for free if it‚Äôs a self care app; we can be dedicated without spending money! x 

All in all, great app, but popups and adds can show throughout. If you can‚Äôt handle that, Fantastic self care is the app for you (subscription popups occur less often)
title: Great App But..

review:
Beautiful layout, informational articles and quizzes, but the typos are distracting. For example, when reading about my Jungian personality type in romantic relationships, the results read: "INFJs thrive in relationships where their partner puts in an equal amount of effort.
They tend to look for partners who are trustworthy and encouraging. They want to feel fully loved and accepted as they are in a relationship and give up on their partner."

This was more than likely supposed to say "WON'T give up on their partner". If the typos could be located and corrected, this app would be 5 stars.
title: Beautiful and insightful, but the typos...

review: The UX is beautiful. The colors, themes, and ease of use are great. That‚Äôs really where the value stops. The questionnaires are awful quality and truthfully pose a risk to potential mental health patients being told they don‚Äôt have something they may actually have. The anxiety quiz only looks at some of the physical expressions of anxiety that can be present for some cases‚Ä¶but not all. It asked almost none of the mental questions such as how often someone is worried, are they unable to sleep because they‚Äôre nervous/worried/etc.. The Introvert/Extrovert quiz is another where the content is severely lacking. For the price, you need a content strategist with a background in mental health. Because at this point it‚Äôs overpriced for crap content.

review: This app has a great interface. I got it because my Autistic son wanted a mood tracker like mine. I thought this one would be easy enough for him to navigate. He can put in a daily mood, add a journal entry, but we can only select 5 activities for the day. This is a problem for me. I need to be able to track things like what time he went to bed, if he ate healthy or junk food (which is rare), if he had a rough day at school, so on and so forth. It would be a great resource to me to have everything unlocked. But $1.99 a week is a bit steep for our already tight budget. Granted I didn‚Äôt test them all, but I clicked on the first 5 tests, and they all asked me to ‚Äúsign up‚Äù or ‚Äústart my free trial‚Äù after clicking get started. Assuming the free ones would be at the front instead of at the end of that list. (If I‚Äôm wrong I do apologize).

Having an Ad before every test or at the end of every test seems more manageable (or at the very least more acceptable in my opinion) than having a subscription show up for each test you try.

Again I know that the ‚Äúessentials‚Äù of the app aren‚Äôt paywalled, simply stating to new users that if they are trying to use this app strictly for the tests, there‚Äôs a paywall.
title: For Tests in Specific

review:
Like MANY other people have said‚Ä¶the subscription requirement made me lose all interest. I wouldn‚Äôt mind paying a one time fee, provided it was all-access. But I refuse to meddle with subscription based programs. 

There‚Äôs already way too many things out there that require a subscription just for someone to use the product. I‚Äôd much prefer a one time all access fee. Or, maybe some features being completely free - maybe with ads (if the ads aren‚Äôt obnoxiously abundant), and then having a premium access fee. 

Anyways, I would‚Äôve kept using the app if it weren‚Äôt for the paywall. I like it, but money is becoming more and more difficult to come by these days.
title: Ugh‚Ä¶another paywall

review:
I needed that. 
Some of us know ourselves best and rarely question who we‚Äôve become thru all of life‚Äôs hardships and difficulty.  
It‚Äôs a cruel world for a gentle soul. 
It may take what once may have been a guardian Angel & make a warrior of them. 
It‚Äôs pretty amazing that the words: worrier & warrior are so similar, yet so different. 
The worrier often dwells, while the warrior acts. 
Perhaps we become a mysterious mixture of both. 
Which ever or whomever one does become, just remember, the only true form of control is self control; moreover, beyond a certain level of maturity (or age if you prefer), the only form of discipline is self discipline.  When it comes to our power: make your own choices and be responsible & accountable thereof, that‚Äôs where the real power is at. 
When the power of love overcomes the love of power, then we may have peace.

title: Something evil

review:
The tests on this app aren‚Äôt valid. Not only do the tests cost money but they also encourage self diagnosing. I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs a warning saying ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a valid diagnosis, just a reason to talk to a professional.‚Äù but if there isn‚Äôt, that is harmful & misleading. No online quiz or test can give real diagnoses, only professionals can. If you relate to the questions they ask, please reach out to a REAL therapist, psychologist or a professional in general. 
I advise you to take these tests off your app because either way, warning or not, some people will still think of it as a real diagnosis.
Thank you for reading, have a pleasant rest of your day/night.
title: The tests on this app are NOT valid or real diagnoses

review: This is something that I really really needed. They have lots of tests to help me learn more about myself. It seems so wonderful. I can see how things like mood tracking and such would be helpful for many people and I did quite like the games. However the tests felt like they either gave obvious or incorrect answers (I took most of them for fun, just wanting to see what they might say).

There‚Äôs a quiz titled ‚Äúemotional burnout‚Äù and some 90% of the questions asked about how tired you usually are from work‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs an introvert/extrovert quiz on here too that basically will tell you whatever you wanna hear based off your simple answers of what you prefer when it comes to outside vs inside activities. title: Ok but a therapist might be better

review:
Multiple rudimentary spelling errors throughout the app, extremely low effort ‚Äúpersonality quizes‚Äù that are literally no different from the ‚Äúquizes‚Äù that were common in the 2012 Facebook era. 
Vague and abstract results, with boring and obvious question pathing.

     I took a test on my ‚Äòlove language‚Äô and it was literally ‚ÄúDo you prefer gifts or physical touch from your significant other‚Äù reworded 30 different times. I‚Äôm being serious, and guess what the result was, after choosing ‚Äúphysical touch‚Äù for all 30 questions I was told I preferred a physical relationship! I never would‚Äôve guessed!ü§° 

     I can‚Äôt believe they ask you to pay 9$ a week for this trash, it‚Äôs an app made for people who take astrological signs serious, actually correction, it‚Äôs an app used to take advantage of people like that. 9$ a week will literally cover the copay of seeing an actual therapist. Stop letting pathetic companies and devs get rich off taking advantage of people, and find someone who actually KNOWS how to help.
title: What a terrible excuse for a money grab
userName: I test so you sont have to

review:
First off- this app misleads you with a test that you complete but instead of giving the results, they prompt you to download this app. Why did I fill out a test? 

Second- you cannot cancel the subscription. It‚Äôs not under your iTunes account nor is there an option in your app Settings. 

There‚Äôs also no direct link to contact support from the app. I had to look here for the company website and support information. That‚Äôs very suspicious behavior. The Terms of Use is incorrect about canceling the subscription and so is the app description here.

My career is in CX/UX so I‚Äôm seeing very big red flags. I‚Äôm currently trying to figure out the payment processor used for my payment because it wasn‚Äôt iTunes and I now regret not fully checking before providing my credit card info. 

I was in a sad place mentally and thought this app would help, so that‚Äôs another very disappointing thing. 

Do not get Premium. The app is nice and has great features, but their subscription practices are very shady.

title: Good but could be better

review: I‚Äôve never written an app review, but felt so strongly about this that I thought I‚Äôd warn people. This is the least substantive app I‚Äôve ever used. It has a nice interface and design, but contains almost nothing. A handful of short quizzes that are incomprehensible and littered with spelling and grammatical errors. You get a one week free trial and then it automatically charges you $8.99 a month. I think the developer is just counting on people forgetting to cancel the auto renewal, so they can scam $9 out of you. There is so little substance to this app that it‚Äôs not even worth downloading. I imagine the developer paid for fake reviews for it to have this many stars.
title: Beware: this app is a SCAM

review: Now in 2022 we‚Äôre out here paying for decent mental health. I am broke, and cannot afford ‚ÄúBreeze Plus,‚Äù and if I try paying $8.00 a week for this, my mental health might start declining rather than getting better. I can‚Äôt ever find a ‚Äútest‚Äù for free. The cards that are given for free don‚Äôt help much but track things that you probably already knew. I know that these companies have to make money somehow, but I do wish that there was someone out there who would be generous enough to publish an app like this that is completely free. I recommend finding an app to track your mental health that won‚Äôt make you pay for these necessary services.
title: This Is The Time We Live In‚Ä¶

review:
The concept is nice, but this needs an editor desperately. Even if the mood journal and quizzes were up to par, it‚Äôs hard for me to imagine them being worth the price per week ($9). The spelling and grammar are deeply flawed, which would be annoying on its own, but reaches the point of preventing comprehension sometimes - ie., I can‚Äôt guess what mood ‚Äúanticipated‚Äù is meant to be. Some of the quizzes are abbreviated versions of typical inventories (misspelled), and some of them are fully invented nonsense. One had an answer set that seems to be the same no matter how you score. 

PS - I DO NOT WANT A DEVELOPER RESPONSE. THIS IS FOR THE VALUE AND REFERENCE OF OTHER POTENTIAL USERS, AND IF I DESIRED DEVELOPER INPUT I WOULD USE THE CONTACT FUNCTION.
title: Poor Value for Cost

developerResponse: {'id': 27830288, 'body': "Thanks for taking the time to provide us with feedback and letting us know about the issue. We'll look for a solution. Also, we're very happy to know you enjoy the mood tracker and hope you'll enjoy the tests and courses as well!", 'modified': '2022-02-03T14:26:11Z'}
review:
I took a couple of tests and as someone who derives great joy out of helping others and laughs constantly, two areas of improvement of mine are apparently ‚ÄúEmpathy and Happiness‚Äù yet as someone who also has an incredibly addictive personality two of my greatest strengths are apparently ‚ÄúSelf Control and Discipline‚Äù I don‚Äôt trust this app very much for the tests.

The ability to track your mood daily and see trends with a variety of different emotional states is very cool and I could see this being immensely useful.
title: The tests seem very arbitrary but the daily mood tracker is excellent

review: I got this app a little over a week ago and it is exactly what I was looking for: an easy way to keep track of my emotions and the events accompanying them. I especially liked that I could create multiple ‚Äúcards‚Äù a day. The only issue I have, to the point where I‚Äôve considered finding a new app, is that when I create a new card it often is created for the next day. For example the cards I created for today, February 16, have been logged for tomorrow, February 17. If there is any way to resolve this issue that would greatly encourage me to continue using the app.
title: Confused

review: First of all, they don‚Äôt send you a reminder when it‚Äôs time to cancel your subscription like they say they will. Then there‚Äôs NO clear way to cancel. Luckily, Apple refunded me but I still can‚Äôt figure out how to cancel and no one is answering my messages. Beyond that and the fact it‚Äôs $9/WEEK, the tests are useless and very clearly no professional, might as well take a Buzzfeed quiz. The questions are way too simple and the answers are so limited that an accurate result would be impossible to achieve. The only good thing about the app is how it looks. Idk how this app has been rated positively. I‚Äôd give zero stars if I could.
title: Needs a lot of work

review: While the idea of this app is very nice, it needs some work. First of all there are a ton of typos in the quizzes I‚Äôve taken so far. When you‚Äôre malting monthly for an app I kind of expect it to be a little more streamlined and not have so many grammatical, and spelling errors, seems sloppy. I‚Äôd also suggest a way to go back to your last question on the quizzes, if you change your mind you have to start the entire quiz over. Definitely a super cute and fun idea for an app but just needs a little more tweaking!
title: Needs work

review: I did the one week free trial. I cancelled it before the week was up and deleted it from my phone. The tests were not very accurate. I love taking personality tests and similar things. I didn‚Äôt learn anything new about myself. There were numerous typos and one of the tests wouldn‚Äôt give me a result. I took it multiple times and every time it said that my results were inconclusive. If you don‚Äôt know anything about yourself or your personality then it might be useful, but if you already know your personality type, this will be nothing new. Hopefully they will improve it overtime.
title: Not worth the time

review: As someone who understands psychology very well and business, this app is shameful.  The answers and results they give you are more like an astrology description that appear very specific but they is really general information that applies to everyone.  It is super expensive at $9 a week, and I saw there ad on Facebook after posting how I am upset at the moment.  Obviously, they know how to target people.  In addition, they try to upsell you with ads for online therapy.  Talk about double dipping with ads and expensive subscriptions.  The most expensive subscription I have ever seen on the App Store by far.
title: This app is a joke pandering and profiting off insecurities

review: The intro test that determines everything: it offers two answers per question that are usually both so inaccurate that making either choice feels wrong, or the question is lacking an element that would make a marginally satisfactory choice possible. If it were a small number of questions like this it would be fine, but it's most of them. It makes me think the test results can't be accurate enough for it to provide practical and useful recommendations. I pushed through 60 of 70 questions before realizing I'd never be able to trust the app's suggestions for me.
title: Couldn't get past the intro test

review:
This app will charge you money for information you can find on the internet for free. If you‚Äôre going to spend money, look into specialists for your problems. Breeze is nothing more than a scam, and it‚Äôs disgusting that they profit off of people at all.

Edit to the response I‚Äôve gotten: the fact that you see no issue or contraction in charging people (especially the amount, I mean my gosh) for just a mood tracker shows that you don‚Äôt care. Don‚Äôt pretend you‚Äôre here for the betterment of mental health. It‚Äôs an easily profitable market, and you are part of the problem. Specialists already cost money; apps like this should not.
title: Scam

{'id': 35613838, 'body': "Dear Kate, thank you so much for this feedback!

review:
I downloaded this app because one of their quizzes was advertised to me on Instagram.

The quizzes were enjoyable when taken with a grain of salt. It‚Äôs important to note that you should not consider the app‚Äôs prediction of your mental health as a diagnose for various mental illnesses such as bipolar depression or ADHD. 

Lastly, one of my only critiques is that the app is very focused on positivity - which is not always helpful for me as I work on my mental health. I tend to lean towards neutrality and acceptance personally. 

If positivity tends to be encouraging and nice for you, then I think you will enjoy this app.
title: Very focused on positivity

review: They make it seem free, but you literally can‚Äôt do anything without buying a subscription in the app. I hate when apps do this. review: Pretty much all of the useful content is behind a subscription paywall that honestly isn‚Äôt that cheap. This could be fun for independent adults that have too much time and money on their hands and are interested in comprehensive personality tests and journaling, but I would argue that the free version of the service just doesn‚Äôt offer enough for everyone else.

developerResponse: {'id': 24711592, 'body': "We're sorry you have such a low opinion about Breeze. Please note that we don't say Breeze is an alternative to a specialist. We recommend Breeze as a tool to improve your mental health and to help you progress faster when you work with a specialist. According to the feedback we get, it helps. developerResponse: {'id': 26319443, 'body': "Thank you for providing us with such profound feedback! It's really important for us and we appreciate it. We'll definitely consider it while working on updates.", 'modified': '2021-11-17T10:27:49Z'}
review:
I tried this app on a whim and quickly bounced off it. Its strongest point is the the daily check-in tool. You enter brief notes about your mood and current activity, and you can track daily progress over time. This would serve well for someone practicing cognitive behavioral therapy or someone who wants to quit an addictive habit like smoking. 

My biggest issues with the app were the personality tests and the outdated language. The personality tests are very narrow in focus and frequently used biased language. The love language test, for instance, assumes romantic involvement, and frames most of the options in terms of partners. Many of the others have the similar shortcomings. The depression test was the strongest one, likely because it is an actual psychological mood indicator backed up by research, and I did not feel that the results were influenced as strongly by bias from me or the test. For an app that asks for a paying subscription, I feel that the developers could spend more resources on getting similar tests that are up to date and backed by research. 

As far as language is concerned, it is not inclusive. There was the partner-focused terminology in the love language test, and overall there is an abundance of either the neutral ‚Äúhe‚Äù or ‚Äúhe/she‚Äù where the neutral ‚Äúthey‚Äù would suit better. It‚Äôs a small detail, but it becomes large since people who are drawn to apps like this also struggle with some version of gender and body dysphoria, or inclusion issues in general. Using more inclusive language recognizes that more than one type of person exists and validates the experience of people who feel like outsiders irl.
title: Useful as a mood check-in tool but shallow

review:
This app is not what it says it is. It looks great as far as the design and the concept. I signed up for the free trial today and there is no way to cancel it. I cannot find it in the app like it says it should be (under my account settings). There is no direct way to contact support. It is not under my Apple subscriptions settings in my phone, so I may be getting changed and the app has my personality and such wrong with no way to change it. I looked further into it and now I‚Äôm concerned.
In addition to all of that, I tried out some of the tests and both times I took the so-called personality test, it was absolutely 100% wrong, Like, I gave it a second chance and re-took it and on questions that I wasn‚Äôt quite sure on I tried to look at them again. It was a difficult result that time but still completely wrong. I am half writing this in hopes the app developer will actually respond and give me some help to this app, because there is no way to actually get customer support through the application. In addition to all of this, the Instagram posts don‚Äôt seem to even make sense as they seem to have been poorly poorly translated from another language. I have nothing against any aspects of this in general and most is still able to be understood, but if you are expecting me to pay almost $10 every single WEEK (not month) for this app, you should get someone to help you translate and edit. I just want to get rid of it before they start taking money.

title: Well....

review:
I have been using the app for a few weeks now, and it is a good app. I really like it. It‚Äôs potential seems very large. I love being able to log my emotional state in about 30 seconds; once you get the hang of it, and set up the icons to things more in your life. It‚Äôs simple and to the point. The stats page is the best part of this app.

   I am not a big fan of the ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù section. But you can tell it is a work I progress, and that is getting better with the very nice regular updates. I did pay for the year Premium, I hate ads. If you don‚Äôt mind ads, this app is a steal for free. Just pay attention to what you clicking on, to many reviews where people are just not paying attention. Read before you click.

    Some con‚Äôs are ‚ÄúNotifications/Reminders‚Äù
      -Give the ability to create as many reminders as needed. Don‚Äôt want to clog up my iOS reminders. Currently, Breeze only lets you set 1 reminder inside the app. I like things all wrapped up and contained in the apps themselves.
     -The cloud slider is too limited, if I am angry, frustrated, even frightened. The words to pick from are there‚Ä¶but the slider and cloud only has Unhappy, sad, bad, normal, good, great, happy. When I‚Äôm angry, bad and sad, are not quite the right ones for me.I know the key words are there I would just like some angry types in there. It would make it easier to quickly identify those times from the front page.

Remember this is a tool not, not a magic pill to cure what ever you think you have. Because if you think this will fix you, then you haven‚Äôt seen a professional yet, or didn‚Äôt listen to them. You need to use it, and see the professional together.

      In reality, the reminders is the only actual con, the slider is just a personal preference. Fix that reminders issue, and it will be a 5 start app. IMO.
title: A great tool.

review:
2.5 / 5 ‚≠êÔ∏è

I added a mood but accidentally saved it with an uppercase letter. This app doesn‚Äôt let you edit an existing emotion (to rename or change the icon). Instead I deleted and re-added my custom emotion with all lowercase letters, but somehow it didn‚Äôt wipe the database when I deleted because it reverts back to the previous capitalization. Very frustrating. Let me properly change capitalization and let me edit any/all moods. -1 ‚≠êÔ∏è

Because this app doesn‚Äôt let you edit existing or custom emotions, I tried replacing one by deleting the original. Unfortunately, the icon used in the original is not available in the icon list (piggy bank icon) or I did not see it after looking through three times. This is either poor design or poor oversight. -1 ‚≠êÔ∏è. I would like more icons to choose from, like yoga.

This is otherwise a lovely app, beautiful to look at and easy to use. I‚Äôve used it less than a week but I want to see if this app makes it easy for me to understand the effects of things like sleep quality, exercise, and other activities on my mood. I‚Äôve only briefly glanced at the graphs and look forward to diving into these after a decent amount of data collection.

Every time I enter a mood, the app bugs me to rate it with a pop up that blocks all other activity until dismissed. This is an aggressive design tactic that I wish dies in a fire. Please use a more gentle method. I haven‚Äôt been using this all consistently or long enough to provide a review that I would deem thorough enough. This is annoying. Hopefully it will stop asking now. -0.5 ‚≠êÔ∏è.
