If you like the major Breeze functions, feel free to email us at support@basenjiapps.com to learn about our special offers and promotions.\n As for the errors, we're working on fixing this issue.", 'modified': '2021-10-05T07:38:19Z'}
review:
The thing I love about millennials and Gen Z is that most of them are concerned for their mental health and trying to break those generational curses. So, as with anything, companies have jumped on this. Some good things are we are able to find apps and info almost anywhere. However, the bad side is greed. And, yes, I‚Äôm going to say greed here, despite everyone‚Äôs love affair with capitalism and everyone NEEDING to make a profit. The health industry is where I REALLY can‚Äôt excuse the greed as this can be a matter of life and death. I downloaded the app (based on an add on Instagram of all places; I should have known something was up because it was on there, lol) and started reading it. I thought this would be a nice digital journal and tracker; it looks great, I‚Äôll give it that. I saw a free trial and that caused me to pause. I‚Äôve used these apps before and never had a free trial. Were there pays versions? Yes, but I was able to use the app pretty well without paying anything. I dismissed the pop up and hope it didn‚Äôt sign me up for a free trail, anyway. I‚Äôll check in a moment when I delete this app. 
Now, the reason for how I started this review. I saw the ‚Äúpremium‚Äù area. This app is $8, which I thought wasn‚Äôt too bad for a monthly fee, but then I saw that I‚Äôd misread that. It‚Äôs $8 A WEEK?! Not only does that defeat the entire purpose of what this app is supposedly trying to do (a lot of our mental issues stem from the pressures created by capitalism, yet here‚Äôs an app jumping right on in there, pushing it in our faces more), but $32 a month seems way too much for a journal and info that I‚Äôve seen all over the internet already. I could pay around $32 once for a digital journal and go browse Psychology Today and have the same thing as this app. Not to mention, there are spelling errors galore on here; I‚Äôd gladly offer my help for free. Oh wait‚Äîthat would be dumb to help for free when you‚Äôre making $32 a month off people. People, there are cheaper/free apps. Good websites with good information for free. Use those instead. Save your $32 and get an actual therapist/counselor who can help you make a plan to cope and live better.
title: This app should be ashamed of itself.

review:
Mood tracking feature seems great, but the other features need a lot of work, especially the tests/quizzes. Most of the tests are horribly worded and almost incomprehensibly vague (poor word choices and poor phrasing) - especially the personality tests. The courses also seem to be lacking - the information is very basic and you can only read one page of a given course per day. You could easily get all of the information at once from a two minute google search. 

Most importantly, though, the wording on their MDQ test is poorly done - the way they phrased the hypomania/mania questions aren‚Äôt as specific as the real MDQ, they just aren‚Äôt phrased in the right way at all. It‚Äôs like they didn‚Äôt understand what some of these questions are supposed to be looking for. They switch between past and present tense, and they made some of the qs sound like a weird personality quiz instead of asking about distinct, episodic symptoms. The real MDQ is not like this at all, and it really shouldn‚Äôt be hard to get the wording right considering how widely this (literally standardized) tool is used in professional settings. 

Additionally, the other tests on personality and temperament don‚Äôt leave any room for nuance or extenuating/influencing factors (like anxiety disorders, inattention due to ADHD, triggers from past traumas, current depressive or manic symptoms, medical illnesses, etc). These tests obviously aren‚Äôt serious diagnostic tools or anything but at least include limitations and a disclaimer of how other current conditions may skew results - it can be hard enough to separate your mental illness from your personality when you‚Äôre unwell, and letting your mental illness become your identity can have disastrous long term consequences.

On a lesser note, the emotional intelligence test is kinda buggy. There is no way to get a high empathy score because somehow the scoring is calculated wrong. I know how dumb this sounds, but I‚Äôm highly empathetic almost to a fault - I have a really hard time not taking on other people‚Äôs emotions, I‚Äôm the therapist friend/family member but also an emotional sponge. I can sympathize and understand the thought processes and reasons behind the emotional reactions of literally anyone, regardless of how irrational they may seem. Just frustrating to be told that I‚Äôm lacking a skill that I‚Äôve had an abundance of my whole life.
title: Tracking feature is good, everything else needs work.
